results.title: Hollow Knight
results.brief_description: Hollow Knight is an award-winning platforming game developed by Australian indie studio Team Cherry.

constellations_primary.name: Silent adventures (Hollow Knight - Education)
constellations_primary.description: Videogames, film and TV usually rely on the spoken word to communicate character and story. It wasn’t always this way. Although we may think of ‘silent films’ as in the past, there are contemporary videogames and films that shy away from using the spoken word.

constellations_other.name: Creepy crawlies onscreen
constellations_other.description: This constellation celebrates creepy crawlies on screen, whether they are benevolent heroes like Buddy the spider of Sbug Games’ Webbed (2019), inscrutable arthropods, or arachnid villains.

results.description:
Hollow Knight is an award-winning platforming game developed by Australian indie studio Team Cherry.

Players explore vast underground catacombs of the ruined Hallownest kingdom. Much of the map is locked off to the player in the beginning but becomes accessible after the player finds key objects or gains new or enhanced skills.

Initially created through a successful Kickstarter campaign, Hollow Knight has playful animation, slick game mechanics and a unique gothic aesthetic that has seen it sell over a million copies worldwide.
description_for_label:

results.title: Hacknet
results.creator_credit: Fellow Traveller and Team Fractal Alligator
results.brief_description: Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

constellations_primary.name: Hack the planet
constellations_primary.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

results.description:
If you’ve ever wanted to know what hacking is really like, Hacknet is the game for you. Simulating a true-to-life terminal environment, the game tasks the player with using computer commands similar to what a real hacker would use. These skills are put to use solving the murder of a character named Bit, who contacts the player through a computer program initiated after their death.

Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

results.title: Giovanni Pastrone
results.brief_description: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria.

constellations_primary.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_primary.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

results.description: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria. The film broke new artistic ground by using special effects to re-create the eruption of Mount Etna and the naval battle of Syracuse, but its biggest legacy is the ‘Cabiria’ shot: the tracking shot. Pastrone mounted a camera on a dolly to trail the action in a scene, and this new technique was quickly adopted by filmmakers at the time.
description_for_label: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria. The film broke new artistic ground by using special effects to re-create the eruption of Mount Etna and the naval battle of Syracuse, but its biggest legacy is the ‘Cabiria’ shot: the tracking shot. Pastrone mounted a camera on a dolly to trail the action in a scene, and this new technique was quickly adopted by filmmakers at the time.

results.title: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)
results.brief_description: Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks.

constellations_primary.name: Clones, doubles and doppelgangers
constellations_primary.description: Multiple characters and doubles materialise in this Constellation inspired by the pioneering special effects of Georges Méliès.

results.title_for_label: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)
results.description:
Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks like multiple exposures, split-screens, time-lapse photography, dissolves and hand-colouring. He even accidentally invented the jump cut when his camera jammed.

Between 1896 and 1913, Méliès directed over 500 films. He described them as “little abracadabras” and they were truly magical, inviting audiences on A Trip to the Moon (1902), into The Kingdom of Fairies (1903) and to enjoy a chorus of decapitated heads.
description_for_label:
Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks like multiple exposures, split-screens, time-lapse photography, dissolves and hand-colouring. He even accidentally invented the jump cut when his camera jammed.

Between 1896 and 1913, Méliès directed over 500 films. He described them as “little abracadabras” and they were truly magical, inviting audiences on A Trip to the Moon (1902), into The Kingdom of Fairies (1903) and to enjoy a chorus of decapitated heads.
